ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How Japan's economic challenges (especially in its infamous "Lost Decades" in the 1990s) reflect the current challenges faced by advanced economies like the US and Europe.
Macroeconomic analysis of contemporary issues.
Reasons behind Japan's fast growth and the stagnation and an international and contemporary comparison
We learned about the economic history of Japan, particularly with a focus on monetary policy responses. You definitely become better at macroeconomic analysis.

I gained insights into the forensic macro approach the course highlights, the history and political complexities of the modern Japanese economy, as well as that of my final paper topic's country of choice (Iceland).
Macroeconomic history and policy insights from 20th c. Japan, and the patterns and circumstances for how similar financial and macro crises have manifested elsewhere

A terrific set of 'forensic macro' tools, a deep body of knowledge about the recent economic history of Japan as well as the policy decision that have shaped it, and an insight into how world-class economists look at solving massive systemic problems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is highly effective in showing that Japan's economic challenges do provide an effective framework to evaluate the vulnerabilities of the global economy today. Students get to learn about a wide range of macro and policy issues, and Prof. Roach structures the class extremely well and focuses it on the theme of the "Lessons of Japan," but also ties it to relevant, present-day topics (i.e. economic policies during COVID-19, Biden's infrastructure bill, etc).
The course was probably one of the most interesting economics electives I've taken and Professor Roach's facilitation of the class was firm but fair.
Good balance

Strengths: Professor Roach is a really nice person, and the course material is very practical. Drew is also a fantastic TF. They definitely are there to help answer any questions you have, and they provide really detailed feedback on everything you work on. The grading was very fair, especially if you put in the work.
Weaknesses: I feel the grading breakdown was weird. The student presentations we worked on took so much time, but it only counted for 10% of your grade. The readings also became very repetitive after a while, as were some class discussions.

Strengths - Professor Roach structures the course very well. Readings are intentional, organized and very manageable. Lecture/discussion style mixed with student presentations work well, and offer a unique opportunity to present and receive (very) detailed feedback. 

Weaknesses - If any, were probably just the Zoom format this year; but, that's unavoidable. Given the format, I still think the course was very rewarding.

It is the perfect economics seminar. Prof. Roach arms you with the confidence and the substance alike to think critically about policy in Japan and beyond. Feedback is extensive, engagement is wonderful (we are expected to genuinely master each week's readings, and this truly enriches our discussions) and assignments are fun, especially if you take the time to start them with time to spare before they are due.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof. Roach's seminars werehighly effective. The short breaks during the seminar is highly appreciated (and I hope it's kept even in offline classes, a 2 hour seminar can be long!) and the mix of professor lectures, discussion questions, and student presentations is well-balanced.
The class was overall well-adopted to COVID, with professor facilitation ensuring everyone got to speak in class even in the leminar format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Highly recommend the class to any student interested in current-day macro and policy issues, even if the student is not interested in Japan or East Asia, as the class aims to show how Japan's experience is also relevant for other economies.

Yes, if you are interested in financial crises, this is one of the best courses at Yale for it that is not in a quantitative context. With the lack of interesting electives in ECON to begin with, don't pass this up.
Yes prof knows so much
Yes! Professor has a really deep understanding of the issue and is kind to offer many help and insight.
I think this is a great Econ seminar. You definitely have to put in the work to get an A, but I really think its worth it.
I would strongly recommend this course to another student. Be prepared to work, but show up, engage, and you'll learn a lot. Definitely one of the most rewarding classes I've taken.

Yes! Prof. Roach has a very well-organized and uniquely structured class, and you'll definitely learn a lot and be supported, even if you feel out of your depth sometimes with the material. If you want an interesting/worthwhile senior seminar without psets, I strongly recommend this one

100% yes. Prof. Roach is a brilliant economist with a deep set of experiences and skills, yet still manages to turn large policy topics into very accessible opportunities for learning and exploration. You get out of this course what you put into it - make sure to stay on top of your readings and you will be rewarded with fascinating, data- and analysis-driven insights into one of the world's most interesting economies, as well as others like it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
